title: Useless

review: Amazon wants you to get used to asking alexa for everything, but while she can answer questions she can't DO simple things like simply search for bluetooth devices, tell you what she finds and you tell her the one to pair to. Nope. Anything remotely technical requires you to use this app. And this app is painful to use. It starts off tyrying to push echo dot conversations on me. It's got 3 buttons that all seem to do the same thing (start conversations with people over echos). If you tell alexa to conncet to bluetooth she tells you to use this app (why? Its the 21st century! Why cant you just find and pair without me having to manually do it in an app), but she then says to install the skill in smart home. Smart home, list devices.. Cant find bluetooth speakers. Ok, skills, i guess i have to install a stupid skill for bluetooth. The skills section of the app is a hot mess. The search funtion flatout DOES NOT WORK. On top of that, apparently we're still in the dark ages of smart devices because every vendor under the sun has their own stupid skills app they want you to install on alexa. This s reams of no standadizations yet. Alexa shouldnt need to learn "skills" to connect to smart devices. She has to simply because smart device manufacturers havent standardized things yet. Everyone of them wants to be primma donna with their own skill app, so in addition to painfully digging for it, you have to pray the vendor actually put time into making it work (theres a reason they have star ratings on the skills...ugh). Anyways, i have to google up how to pair alexa to bluetooth speakers (that very necessity means alexa is failing at her GD job, bc she tells me to go to this stupid app instead of doing it directly, and this app is a hot mess to use). There is a bluetooth section. But the app can only seem to find ONE device at a time. Your device didnt show up? Hit back and try again, like you're at a roullette table hoping your number comes up. Ugh! Finally my speakers show up, and the app sits there trying to connect. My phone takes like 2 seconds to connect to them when I do it through settings. But alexa (echo dot) takes forever. Why?! Then you exit, try again, but she lists them as a decice she knows BUT IS NOT PAIRED TO. PAIR TO THE GD SPEAKERS FFS! You click on them in the list, app cooks then finally pairs. Does alexa say anything to automatcally confirm she's using the speakers? No. So you have to ask her something stupid to get her to speak and see if shes using the speakers. This way more painful then it should be. You can make a list using her, but to delete it "use the app". Why? DELETE THE GD LIST WHEN I TELL YOU! And lists are useless. I make a list of songs. Tell alexa to play the songs in the list. Nope. She can't do that. I make a list of numbers. Give me the sum total of those numbers. Nope. They need to add WAY more functionality to lists if they're going to be of any use. They're basically one dimensional string arrays you cant do anything with. So close yet so far. Next we have the tplink smart plug amazon suggested we buy when we got the echo dot. Well we have a living room lamp thats a pita to turn on and off so it'd be great to just tell alexa to do that. Try to get that thing going is a pita in and of itself (plug in, install ANOTHER app, hook to it, hook to network, create yet another login, etc). Finally get it going as a smart plug. Now we have to pair it with alexa. Open skills, install more crap, look for device IN THE APP bc alexa is too stupid to pair using just voice, finally get them paired. "Alexa turn on the (light name)". "I'm sorry I can't find that device." YES YOU CAN! I'M LOOKING AT IT RIGHT IN YOUR APP! I CAN EVEN USE YOUR APP TO MANUALLY TURN IT ON AND OFF! WHY CAN'T YOU VOICE COMMAND IT?! This was one of the reasons we got the echo dor and it CAN'T DO IT'S GD JOB! They need to make alexa be able to do more of this maintenance crap through her instead of this stupid app. They need to standardize smart devices and get rid of skills. But if they force you to install skills, FIX THE GD SEARCH. This app is painful and makes me want to get rid of alexa.

author: carsoncarroll7
title: Not working

review:
To begin with, let me say I love my Echo and all the dots I have spread around the house.  I have converted much of my home light switches to z-wave switches, and have a Wink 2 hub.  I have z-wave plugs everywhere, and am enjoying my home automation, especially when it works with Alexa.  I also enjoy the multi-room music capability, or did when it worked.

With progressive ‚Äúupdates‚Äù to the app, it seems that functionality continues to step backwards.  The app now refuses to communicate with my early generation Echo (bought during the Beta-wonder if they‚Äôre trying to make me update), and now the multiroom music just doesn‚Äôt want to work.  Further, the app has taken to freezing up, especially if I try to enter the settings section of the app to figure out what‚Äôs wrong with my hardware.

As you can tell, I am an amazon fan, and really enjoy the Alexa environment; however, Amazon is not necessary for my Wink and all my remote controlled devices, and I‚Äôm close to looking into the new Google device or the Invoke.  

Frustrating that something that started so strong seems to be falling fast in reliability.

title: Bad Job

review:
New update is takes away ability to control play on echos, dots, and taps from app. When Amazon first came out with Echo I loved it and have a device in every room. Now I think it's suffering from it's popularity and Amazon can't handle the increased use of its service and is trying to reduce the load on its service reducing the functionality of the app and slowing the  responses from the devices. Now finding devices responding to random noise as wake word and sometimes not responding to wake word unless your a foot away and yelling, might as well use physical controls. Response to commands is deteriorating, Will give Alexa command to play song, Alexa responds with the correct title to the song but says it's not in the library even though I'm looking at the song with the exact title in my library. If I keep repeating the command with Alexa giving the EXACT SAME CORRECT SONG TITLE back every time eventually instead of saying she can't find the song it will start playing.  This may not sound like a review of the app but the app only has a use if the Alexa AI functions usefully. Amazon needs to focus on the basic functionality and loose the mostly useless and stupid "skills."

This app is driving me to drink. At least the Smart Home section. It continually drops connections and adds old ones randomly without going through discovery. I used to have TP-Link smart plugs but I've since replaces the ones that controlled lights to HUE. Ive disabled and deleted these plugs, but they constantly come back. They will have the same name as the HUE lights so it gets confused. It will work fine then randomly it will say the HUE device isn't responding, but it works fine if I go into the Phillips app or any of the other third party HUE apps to turn them on or off. 

The latest patch added the ability to delete devices, but they still come back and it throws Alexa for a loop when three devices, two of which don't exist, are named living room. 

Please, Amazon, you are an excellent company and Alexa is clearly the future, don't let google pass you by because your app that controls her is garbage.

title: Does not connect. Get the Google product.

review: This app has always been bad when trying to set up Echo. However, I've always been able to get it to connect to the network eventually. Not today, apparently. I've literally spent hours. Between closing and restarting the app, resetting the device with a paper clip and just waiting for the process to fail, I've gotten nowhere. Not sure what kind of network is needed, maybe one with no passwords? The app interface is just bad UX, plain and simple. Hit a back button and end up on the Home screen. Try to join a pw protected network and wait for the connection to fail so you can finally see the password prompt. Complete setup and you are stuck on a video tutorial screen. Once you get the thing working, the device is great (not the app). Just pray you don't ever need to set up again. With all of Bezos' billions, you'd think they could hire some real developers and UX designers.

author: Firsttimeparents
title: Always crashes and is slow.

review:
This app is without a doubt the worst, slowest, least responsive, badly engineered app that I have ever seen. You can literally spend over an hour trying to connect WiFi to your Tap without success. The app slowly, agonizingly takes you from one step to the next before freezing. 
I‚Äôd like to blame it on the slowness of the Fire, but it‚Äôs no better on my iPhone. And that‚Äôs with full WiFi reception. 

However, if you‚Äôre not successful you can always call their help dept. and speak to a rep. The one that I got was minimally conversant in English and had what sounded like an Indian accent- as did all the other people in the room. Her help consisted of reading a manual to me - covering things that had no relevance to my problem.   Not surprisingly, I received no help. 

I did, however, receive an email from Amazon with a request to complete a survey. I complied, explaining my problem and basically asking that they call me. Of course, they did not call. 

Now don‚Äôt get me wrong. I am an Amazon Prime member and am happy with their Prime program, including Prime Pantry. I have, to this date, purchased three Taps, eight Fires and a Dot, most as gifts. 

But after my experiences with this app and their customer support I have come to an unavoidable conclusion. 

It‚Äôs time to try Google.
author: PaulD Esq
title: Time to try Google

review:
So we have an Echo, an Echo Version 2, two dots, a Hue Bridge, eight Hue bulbs and two Iris‚Äôs and everything was working fine. 

Using an iPhone 7S Plus running iOS 11.2.1 I updated the Alexa app yesterday (Jan 3, 2018) and it factory reset everything in the house. Alexa could not find any Amazon devices, smart home devices or groups. Hugely inconvenient considering everything was set up and perfect the day before. 

I guess it‚Äôs my fault for becoming dependent on home automation but it goes to show how fickle it all can be when it goes haywire.

author: pissyshark
title: Garbage

review:
We initially generally liked the app, although we found it somewhat confusing and unintuitive. Then I was spontaneous logged out of the App while travelling. I was trying to resolve my problem that I could not log on for days. 
I tried repeatedly to login. Aside from the annoying process of having to enter cryptogram images, I tried over and over again to login. Each time the app would look like it was accepting my login, only to return me to a fresh login screen. 
I contacted the ‚Äúhelp‚Äù desk via chat.  I was passed from representative to representative on chat, with representatives changing, even in the early stages of our conversation and without notice or explanation for the change. I was told to do things that I had told them I had already done. In the end I was told they would send my case to engineering. I received a simple email of things to try while I waited for a response. That email was a restatement of all the things that were all the basic things that the chat ‚Äúhelpers‚Äù had stubbornly suggested, even though I had already told them I had done those things. 
After again trying to restart my phone, the resumed chat help seemed to have no knowledge of my previous questions. 
Finally, when I heard from engineering I wrote back to say that I had finally gotten the app to connect, for no apparent reason, and after days of trying. 
I asked on question : Does the app not work when traveling outside the USA?
Instead of getting a reply, I‚Äôve now received another email offering to help ‚Äúsolve my problem‚Äù, again with no apparent awareness of my specific situation, and asking me to call. 
I have given hours of my time to this annoying app and unhelpful process. 
I will not call. 
I will use the app that now seems to be working. 
If I have further problems, I will return the device and will not waste my time re-engaging with the unhelpful Alexa help desk. 
It‚Äôs too bad the service is so bad since my family was initially enjoying the Echo/Alexa products.

The ONLY reason I ever open this app is to look at my grocery list at the store. 
That requires minimum 3 clicks to get to every time I open the app, regardless of which route I take to get to it. 
Seriously, if I click on any part of a item in my feed that shows something I added to my list, other than the text of the item, I expect to be brought to the list. Not a drop down showing options of what to do with the item, not a list of all my lists, just the list.
If you are going to have a dedicated task bar along the bottom, one of the buttons should take me to my most recently viewed list items. As it is, the current three are completely useless to me. 
FURTHERMORE, if I am changing the name of an item on my list, and hit DONE or click away, I expect my typing so far to be SAVED, not discarded. 
A. Who do you have designing the interface, and B. can I have their job?

The consistent problem I have is the avalanche of research necessary to plod through learning how to use it. Normally I would give a lower rating because of the mandated learning curve. Yet, everything we have been able to apply has not only been useful, but fun. Consider this: when I was a kid, my parents sometimes still read by candle light. True story. Echo is near magic to me right alongside being able to talk with someone through a hand held communicator and computers that talk. Those things would never be real, right?

review: Easy to set up with a tablet.  Calls and messaging setup comes with the app being on a cellphone or tablet with call and messaging features. Skills setup was slightly challenging in the absence of printed instructions in the box with the Dot.  I had all of my smart plug connected devices enabled and controlled by Alexa in about 10 minutes. I did have to change abbreviated names to full names for Alexa to recognize and complete commands. I am impressed with the limited use I have employed so far. My next test will be disconnecting power and reconnecting to determine if there is continuity with the setup and connection to Amazon echo services since I do not intend to have my DOT connected 24/7 for privacy considerations.

review: It's hard to get it set up I get so far and I get stuck

Here are some helpful tips or troubleshooting that you can do if ever you are encountering some problems in your Echo devices:  *Connecting to your Wifi/Internet -make sure youre not connecting to a adhoc networks, and echo devices requires fast and stable connection so dont expect it to function properly if your connection isnt stable,  -Go to your alexa app>menu (three horizontal lines at the upper left hand of the screen) > settings>choose your echo device>update wifi and follow the steps in setting up your echo device -if you get an error message, make sure that you entered your wifi password correctly, restart your echo device, power cycle your router, reset if still not working or use a different device (even though some of your devices work properly with your wifi connection, the echo device is different, sometimes it depends on the compatibility of your router thats why you should check your ISP as well.)  *Echo device is not responding  -always check if the mic button on the echo device if it is RED because it means that its on MUTE and check on the alexa app if its offline or online.  -sometimes the echo device needs some refreshing, you can restart it by unplugging it from your power source and after full 20 seconds plug it back on again. -or you can move your device closer to your router -or you can power cycle your router -you can reset it as well but resetting the echo device is resetting everything and youre going to set it up again.    Learning is important and doing this basic troubleshootings can save time. Trust me this is based in experience and I know that this is frustrating and disappointing but still technology is not dormant so we should never stop learning as well. It may solve your issues and instead of calling support for this you can save your time :)   -Emblem.

When I'm in the grocery store, I have to constantly keep my phone on by pressing the screen, so that it doesn't go to sleep, because when it does, I have to wait another 30 seconds for the app to load again JUST TO VIEW MY SHOPPING LIST THAT WAS ALREADY OPEN A SECOND AGO!!! review: I have a couple Echo devices around the house and love them for various uses, especially home automation. You need this app to configure those echo devices.  However, Amazon in the past few iterations has added "Alexa Calling" to the app and the echoes and they rope you into activating it. Not only is it a manipulative and sleazy way to get people to "opt-in" (by making it very difficult to avoid opting in and still using the product), it also doesn't let you turn the feature off, you HAVE TO CALL AMAZON CUSTOMER SUPPORT to disable a very invasive unwanted and nearly useless feature.  Super sleazy on Amazon's part. Especially for an app with so many rampant privacy issues.

review: This app was barely passable from the start and hasn't really improved much over time. The shopping list got an office mode a little while back but you can still expect to wait forever to get to it if the phone even thinks there might be a network connection. We can't the app open to cached data and refresh in the background?  Worse, if it suddenly finds a connection it will go back to the home page.   The rest of the features are similarly half-baked and poorly tested. The app is ok for checking up on your Echo but not much else.  Finally, on the latest update Amazon suddenly needs access to every permission on the phone.  Contact list, running apps, phone calls, everything.  I love Amazon as a store and the Echo hardware itself is great. Like so many of their Android products though this app is half baked with a side of underhanded and shady.

review: Much better after the update.

Drop In on Dots is 1 out of 5 stars. I've got excellent bandwidth and an awesome wireless router. After getting the fancy email, I felt very excited about Drop In. Like when the update related for Zune revealing fancy new wireless functionality, it was like a bonus - remember?! Drop in however in my book, should never have been released in its current state. It's not solid, fades in and out, the volume is too low and uses the onboard speaker, breaking the bluetooth connection to that speaker, and is an embarrassment. I had someone excited to experience the new feature, but drop in was dropping out. I hope someone at amazon sees this post and explains why this was released when I'd give it a 2 out of 10 for overall satisfaction. Disappointing.

review: Alexa has made as big of an impact on my life and lifestyle as the very first digital video recorder did. Fifteen minutes out of the box and I knew I'd never be without her. As an example, for the first time in my life (I am almost 60) my shopping list is complete and I can choose whether to purchase an item now or next week. Also all of my "to do's" are kept on one list. With Amazon's generous return policy, if you even think you might like Alexa, and you are a Prime member, ought to try her.

This latest version won't even fully load on the LG G4. The crash pop-up even crashes.  There's a ton of Echo developers, including myself, that will fix these continuous app issues for you. Just ask us.  We actually DO want users to be able to use our skills...  Desktop version has always had FireFox login issues, too.

review: Disappointing. Both Echo and the Alexa app. The weather skill can't even tell you humidity. Now, as of July 28, control of Wemo devices has become erratic and semi-functional. I have updated Wemo device firmware, re-enabled the Wemo account connection, re-dscovered devices within the Alexa app, but it's still extremely retarded, with very long delays between the command and whatever execution it decides to implement (which varies from attempt to attempt.) I might blame Wemo, since it's a terrible app as well, but all devices are currently working fine from the Wemo app. My main motivation with Alexa/Echo was home automation control, but it's not reliable. Waking up to a noise, and saying "Alexa; lights on" should, you know, turn on the lights. But Alexa hesitates for a substantial period of time, then might (or might not) turn on a totally random selection of Wemo devices. Not ready for Prime time, pun intended. Alexa and my Echo devices are mostly just music streaming speakers now, and the only devices with a decent speaker for that purpose are the tall original Echos. Besides, with Amazon devices, unlike Google Home, you can't get the same stream coordinated on multiple devices concurrently. The Echo Show speakers are very directional (and the device is also hard of hearing.) If I could undo the whole mess, I would today.
author: Mike St James

review: I haven't tried it out yet but I'm sure this app is going to be awesome with a capital a

Sometimes Alexa is OK. Like checking the Weather. Sometimes it's not; like doing anything else useful. Sometimes it's good for music. Until it's not a common title and she can't figure it out. Sometimes, it's great for playing music from your paid Unlimited subscription. Unless you want to actually search for a song or album... because the app is completely useless. Amazon's response to that: Alexa is a voice activated tool. Useless. 10/10 would argue with Alexa for hours again.

When I use my phone and open the screen, I see a popup telling my my wifi has been connected... meaning it was disconnected during the phones down time. review: Not sure why so many bad reviews. Seems a lot of reviews are on the device itself and not the app. 2 totally different things. Once paired you really don't need the app. App works great and always has same with the echo itself. Never had 1 issue. It understands me 99.9% of the time the other .1% is because either the tv is too loud but not the device itself. Someone was talking carp about searching music. Just say a name of a song or artist and it will be played. I think most reviews are due to user error and not the device. Sure the app could use a little work but for the most part it works flawlessly. Easy to find skills and set alarms, add more devices and link my smart home devices. I don't know why people say it's hard to connect to WiFi because it is the easiest device I've ever hooked up to my wifi. Its never lost connection either. Only when the power has gone out but as soon as it's back on so is alexa. I have over 70 devices paired with the app and alexa has not once messed up when giving a command to lock a door or turn on a light. I would definitely recommend it over Google home any day.

Sometimes Alexa doesn't understand me and I want to play a specific song or album from Amazon Music Unlimited - you can't, apparently it's just radio and popular. What on Earth and I paying for this service for then? Spotify gives you full control of Alexa music from the app.   Also while the new whole home audio festure is welcome, it's still lacking. Has a great basis to build on but there are some real problems with Alexa too.  The biggest is the inability of Alexa to not play adult content music.  My kids want to play music on it and it just starts dropping f-bombs.  Amazon is aware of this and has said they don't plan on implementing a clean version option like Pandora has. Calling is great, eliminates the need for a home phone for the kids even off the volume levels are kind of low

The app is still as slow and unresponsive than it ever was. Plus, Amazon shoehorned this stupid "calling" feature that I do not want my Echo to have, and I have no way to disable it or opt out. This app is garbage, and the Echo is slowly turning into a paperweight. Won't be long until I give up on it altogether.

review: Ok, I have to say Alexa is just awesome!  With the addition of "Routines", which allow me to setup home automation macros, I have to say this app is now incredible.   Wow!  Also, over the last year, Alexa's ability to answer questions has improved so much, she's now about equal to Google, which is a tremendous improvement.  I have a Google Home Mini only for questions, since Amazon Echo is so far ahead of Google Home for home automation capabilities, but I've figured out Alexa can now answer just about everything Google can. I am NOT a fan of the Alexa calling features, since I have no intention of opening all my contacts up to Amazon, but Alexa is now close to perfect. We'll done Amazon!

review: Fourth Update:  Amazon/Alexa did allow this station back on-line, so all is well, for now.  No complaints at this time.  Great service, and great device (I have the Tap).  So 5 Stars.  Hope it stays this way.  ////  Update:  Wow!  So now we're purging conservative radio stations from the Amazon/Alexa feed, huh?  I tried to ask Alexa to play my favorite radio station, and I got back "105.9 FM WMAL on iHeart Radio isn't available right now."  Just to make sure it wasn't a temporary glitch, I waited and asked again, and got the same, only restated: "105.9 FM WMAL on iHeart Radio is currently not available."  Which is funny (NOT), 'cause I can go straight to iHeart Radio on my Android tablet, and it immediately plays, just fine.  Amazon, you had better stop boycotting/purging stations just 'cause you don't like their content!  Not happy at all with Amazon over this.  Fix now!  Immediately!  Or you will be reported to the FCC!  ////  Second Update:  Finally, Landscape Mode has been restored!!  Thank you, Amazon, for providing this update for all of us tablet owners, and for the disabled who rely on Landscape Mode for their special devices.  As I said before, this has always been a 5 Star application.  Brilliantly thought out.  Superbly executed.  Great UI.  Now that it supports tablets, it is perfect.  Thanks again, Amazon!  BVI User.  ////  First Update: After calling and emailing Amazon, Landscape Mode has still not been restored for their handicapped/disabled users.  Numerous reviews have been posted by other handicapped/disabled people asking why, and no response from Amazon.  Poor customer response and service.  So, down to One Star you go.  What a shame, for an otherwise responsible and squared-away company.  Pay attention to your handicapped/disabled users!  ////  This would have been a 5 Star review...  Until yesterday.  Minus One Star for taking away Landscape Mode.  Hey, some of out here have large screen tablets and are not gonna twist them around just to see your app's screen.  Those of us with Visual Impairments need the widescreen display.  Please make the orientation an option, Landscape or Portrait.  Minus One Star for removing the identifying colors and symbols for our music apps.  Again, those of us with Visual Impairments used to be able to find our iHeartRadio app by looking for the "red square."  The TuneIn Radio app was easily located by looking for the "aqua square."  Granted, I'm sure that the black & white menus look very modern and sophisticated, but they're not friendly for the Visually Impaired.  Please add an option to put the color back.  Otherwise, great app!  I can control my Tap from either my tablet or new iPhone seamlessly.  Just please be considerate of us Visually Impaired people.  Thanks.  5 Stars once you provide these options.  BVI user.

review: If I could give this app a negative review I would. I'm not a huge fan of my dot to begin with but the app just destroys any positive feelings I might have had.   One of the biggest things I use the app for is text to speech on my Kindle books. Not only can I not arrange how I want the icons to look or hide services I don't use, but I can't   search through my books for the title I want or sort them. It is also virtually impossible to just say "Alexa read XXXXX" because she has no idea what I'm talking about.  My roommate foumd the same thing when she tried to get the app to read to her. You have to dig through all the books to find the one you want and then hit play.   Also, Alexa is extremely  spotty with pronunciation (i.e., a character whose name is Manny sometimes gets called Man, sometimes pronounced Many and sometimes pronounced Manny; a character named Colin is sometimes prounced like Cawlin and sometimes like Colon).  All that being said, the biggest thing I hate about the app is that it randomly stops, as if a sleep timer went off and it stops reading. If I wake her up by saying "Alexa", she reads a few more words and then stops or she will randomly start reading again (i.e., a 3 am the book will come back on for a sentence or two and then will stop again). This would continue the whole book if I let it. Amazon says it's most likely the internet connection but I can tell you it absolutely is not.   I realize Alexa was a pioneer in AI in her early days, but one would think Amazon would have improved her since then. Not so much.

Same is true for the smart home devices - one would NEVER use this app to control them given a choice, because it is so clumsy. review: This is good product
Great product.

The UI is a little buggy/klunky and not quite what you'd expect from Amazon.  For example, I was reviewing a skill and couldn't see what I was typing.  There are other cases where the UI seems to freeze or not respond to taps as expected.  Sometimes no visual or tactile tap feedback is apparent.  There is a lot to this app, however, so give it a chance.  Also, for crying out loud, could people please stop reviewing the Echo here? These reviews are for the Android app, not your Echo. Also, please stop calling the Amazon Echo "Alexa".  Alexa is the default wake word or the AI personality, not the device.  It's like calling your iPhone "my Siri".

review: Well, the set up is straight forward. You need to ask the questions as dead on as u can or she either ignore the question or selects the wrong song/play list. I have been using the timer & reminder function for cooking. And of course to not to forget to do something. It is a matter of getting familiar with the settings. The music part is handy for work or for relaxing. The best parts are asking for the time, weather, questions that come to you out of nowhere. As example, recipes for parties. You can have the recipes sent to your phone so don't need to search for pen or paper. Keep in mind as always there are many things you can do with this app. You can listen to weather, keep up with the news by going to the My Skills section. This app is the backbone of Alexa. Once set up & paired it can be a very helpful app. For the one star reviewers to me you need to keep in mind new features are added as the app evolves.

review: Lately, all of my Echo devices are constantly telling me that there was a problem executing the command or that the device lost its connection. All my other devices are connected with no issues and this happens while my FireTV is steadily streaming (and yes, I have more than enough bandwidth for multiple streams, etc). This is most frustrating. The music groups are useless because if you have your device connected to a Bluetooth speaker, it severs the connection and plays the music thru the device (which sounds horrible on a Dot). Furthermore, the Tap can't be added to a music group. Calling one of your other devices is interesting, but it would be more useful as an intercom without having to "answer" with a command. (I want to give my 3-year-old instructions in another room, but he can't answer the call) Calling another device also severs any Bluetooth connections. Alexa had a huge head start, but is quickly falling behind in useful features now that there is competition.

review: Loved my original Alexa. Used in the kitchen as a radio & timer. Just got the Plus with some smart bulbs.  Now i'm lucky if it hears me at all & when it does it only understands half the time again. It's said sorry to me in the last 24 hours more than I've been apologised to in my entire life. So irritating. If your buying the plus for smart bulbs like myself. Don't do it. Every time i say "hall lights on" alexa says " sorry, i couldn't find all lights" i named my hall lights 1 & 2 every time I say "alexa 1 on" its says "sorry i found several devices with that name" "which device would you like"???  On top of that, the app itself has improved but is still rediculously slow. & set up should be automatic & simpler.  I really enjoyed my original alexa. The plus with hue bulbs i thought would be fun. But its quicker to get up & turn the lights on manually than either asking alexa & definitely quicker than using the app.

Being able to walk into my house and play a song i wish i had heard on the radio just by saying hey Alexa play "whatever" or being able to ask her to continue my sports talk show when i walk in is such a simple feature but so cool. It's nice to not have to find a new device when i walk in to reconnect everything i was listening to. The Echo Dot solves all those problems and there price is great. Highly recommended for anyone especially people who dont think they can use  something new like this. But it is so user friendly for all ages. 10/10

review: I love my new Echo! It is really cool! On tablets the calling and texting feature doesn't work but here's a way to fix it. 1. Search on the play store for an app that gives you a free phone number. 2. Type Amazon account into your web browser, and click the 1st or 2nd result and sign in and add the phone number you just got; follow the instructions. 3. Borrow a friend's compatible phone and sign in with your amazon account, then click the middle button on the bottom, follow the instructions. DO NOT ALLOW CONTACTS. IF YOU DO ALL YOUR FRIEND'S CONTACTS WILL BE ADDED TO YOUR ECHO, AND MESS THE WHOLE THING UP. If you've followed these steps, try calling on your Echo. Your Echo will call just phone numbers, not contacts. 4. Delete the Alexa app from your friend's phone. Now you will be able to call! This is the only way to do it without buying a phone. This app is a pain.
Needs much inprovement

All in all, even though the app looks fine and accomplished it's overall functions without too many problems, it simply lacks the functional polish that I would expect from from an international giant like Amazon.

review: No where near as easy to use as Google Assistant / Home apps... No material design for Android... No native option to open Alexa, whereas Google Assistant just hold the home button... Big thing is I don't need to buy hardware with Google for it to work (just use your phone if you want, don't buy any speakers), Amazon are really trying to push you spending money on Echo devices. Also Google Assistant is far far more natural in understanding what you are saying, Alexa requires very precise commands and doesn't always get them right, and I hate the excuse people are saying that "you have to make your own 'skills'", no I really shouldn't need too! This should have machine learning and just understand me however I say it! Google does that perfectly by comparison... And one final thing, I can access, control and delete all my user data with Google, Amazon on the other hand - nothing, and yet Google is apparently the "bad boy" for user data mining!... Bottom line Google is simply the cheapest and highest performing option, and I've now tested both. Sorry Amazon.

review:
I give 5 stars because I love my Alexa devices, but feel the "Routines" feature has a lot of room for growth.  So far, I've been happy with what it can do and have had a little fun playing with it.  I like walking into my office in the morning and saying "Alexa, time to get to work" and having all my lights turn on, followed by news and sports updates.  

Admittedly, my gripe comes from the app's lack of imagination. I envision being able to change the color/dimming of the lighting, and having the option to trigger a particular song/artist/genre of music to begin playing.  My sick, twisted mind hypothesized a scenario where I say "Alexa, it's business time" and the lights dim, change color, and Flight of the Concords starts playing.  Just seems like it could be a lot of fun!

review:
I have ewe-Link automation devices in all my house, when I use the ewe- Link app to control them it is easy and fast but when I use Alexa (Amazon Alexa with echo Dot) Alexa understands the command and send it from Amazon-Alexa‚Äôs Cloud to ewe‚Äôs Cloud (accounts previously linked accordingly) sometimes Alexa respond: The server is not responding, after that sometimes it takes more than 3 minutes to turn on or turn off a device or sometimes it does not do anything to complete the action.
In the other side, sometimes (not very frequent) I have very good experiences (fast response with Alexa and ewe-Link clouds) and I can do whatever I want smoothly with no delays, that makes me believe it is a communication problem between clouds.
We hope developers take action to fix this issue.
Also I want to say with Spotify it works very well always so far.

author: Joti Shepherd

review:
The app overall contains alot of very useful items. Music, shopping list, etc. 
There are a few things that standout as needing immediate correction:
The volume control on the app is the absolute worst I (and hundreds of others) have ever seen. It's glitchy and the user can't even see the volume control under their finger because of the poor design. This causes the volume to go to zero at times as well as jumping up way past where the user wants it to be.
It's time Amazon enable the volume buttons on the phones to work the music volume. (Harmony has done a wonderful job with that on their remote control hub app). 
Additionally, the app must stop refreshing when behind the scenes. It must stay in the state the user placed it before going on to do other things.
Now Alexa herself... She NEEDS a better search engine, ability, and A.I.   I think perhaps Bing is the current search from what I understand. But that's not the whole issue. Alexia seems to be able to find and understand little of the real world and information users ask. 
I expect at least an 8 out if 10 from Amazon. At this time, Alexa and this app are a solid 6 at best. We expect better.

review:
The two things that make Alexa useful to me are:

1. My Music
2. Stringify 

Sadly, though, Amazon‚Äôs announced it will end My Music and Alexa now flags Stringify as unsupported in routines. I can find other solutions for music, but, without Stringify, Alexa routines offer very little function. I‚Äôm now considering a switch to Google Home/Assistant.

‚Äî- Previous Comments ‚Äî-

If you can figure out how to get Alexa to call the Stringify skill from a routine, the integration works beautifully. However, there is nothing in the Alexa UI that helps you through the process. If you try something and it doesn‚Äôt work, there is no diagnostic help. VERY FRUSTRATING.

review: App required with use of Echo devices. The recent update makes using the Echo Dot more convenient. title: The Volume on music is better positioned

review:
I give this app 2 stars for the vital functionality it provides to administer your Echo devices. But, it‚Äôs really a horrendously clunky app. The usability was always bad but it has gotten worse with successive updates. Not only are the aesthetics still bad, but the performance/speed is atrocious. Half of my usage is spent wondering if the pulsating 3 dots are a wait indicator or if the transaction stalled. 

In sloppy updates, recent versions have made the volume control bar harder to use than before. I have to play a song to change the volume in my kids room which means if it‚Äôs up high they get blasted at night when I‚Äôm starting sleep music remotely. The volume slider is crazy hard to touch and the volume number is under my finger. 

Seriously, I can‚Äôt list all the bad usability in this thing but if the performance was more reliable and snappier, I could live with bad design. 

In missing features, why can‚Äôt I set the music volume low and comfortable as a background setting, and get Alexa‚Äôs voice volume high so she‚Äôs not whispering to me when I ask the song name.

title: Completely unusable

review: Alexa is more of a novelty, not much there for practical use. It would be nice if Amazon programmed Alexa to perform more routines when you say a specific command. For instance, it would play a specific type of music station (ie relaxing music or sounds) when I give a specific command (Alexa, time to get ready for bed).  Another nice feature would be to link reminders to Alexa in routines, such as when I say ‚ÄúAlexa, Good Morning‚Äù on a Monday, she would tell me the reminders I have programmed for Mondays. Linking a smart phone ‚Äúreminder‚Äù app to Alexa, to play when a routine is created, would be fabulous!  Right now, aside from asking her to play music (most of what I listen to isn‚Äôt available on Amazon Music) and use her for my morning routine to get weather, traffic, and daily briefing, I don‚Äôt use it much.  It seems to be in an infancy stage even after a couple of years.  It could be great. I look forward to when it is.

SUGGESTION: Please provide native playback (without Bluetooth) of Apple Music and Google Music Play. I am considering to switching to Google device because of this. I understand the protectionist impulse but a successful device and platform in the long run is the one that provides access and doesn‚Äôt limit one.

SUGGESTION: Search for Prime music is still not provided. Echo voice recognition is still not perfect. Why not provide search function just like Amazon Music app does?!

Fixed: Latest GUI change broke the volume control. It is EXTREMELY hard to slide volume control and sometimes accidentally jumps to lowest or maximum volume, risking a damage to your hearing! UPDATE: This issue is now fixed with very nice and responsive volume control. Thank you! This alone gains a whole star rating for me.

There is no way to access the player from the app at all now. It does make me wonder if you are in tune with your customers at all. 

July 2017. Truly wish I had not updated the Alexa app. It is so much harder to navigate. I cannot find the things that used to be fairly easy to locate (music or skills) and the volume control is glitchy and very frustrating to control - overly sensitive, it oscillates between too loud and mute which is extremely frustrating when I am trying to slightly adjust the volume while my husband is asleep. review: First let me say, I think that the Amazon Echo is one of the most awesome gadgets I could imagine. That said, it's hard to understand how Amazon could get the app so wrong. It does what it should, but is slow, disorganized & unbelievably annoying. Why is there no option to set smart home, skills, shopping list or anything else for that matter as the opening screen? Why is it that in order to add a smart bulb or switch as I add to my system that I need to discover ALL devices & then have to delete many Roku channels or Hue presets that I never use?  Why is it not possible to set the device list to alphabetical and for it to remain that way? Why are there no widgets for, example, shopping or to-do lists. And finally, my laptop boots up faster than this app takes to open. Bottom line is I would think some Amazon braniac would be able to improve this. Please Amazon, I beg you, make your software as brilliant as your hardware

review:
I was so excited when Amazon announced the multi-room music feature for the Echo devices.

I was then quickly dismayed to find out that it wouldn‚Äôt work with the two Taps that I have. Seems to be quite the oversight. 

So I got some Dots on Black Friday sales and replaced my Taps. Pretty much one Dot for every room with an Echo Show in the kitchen.

Go to set up my groups starting with am Everywhere group where it plays the same music on every device throughout my house! Yes! This is awesome!

So I decide I want to set up a few more groups for those times that I still want the same music to play in the Living Room and the Kitchen, but not in the bedrooms. Only to discover that once you have a device in one group you can‚Äôt place it in another group. Again... what an oversight.

review:
Feb 2018 review. My external blue tooth speaker will no longer work with Alexa Dot. Period! 

Sept 2017 review-This app continues to devolve with each update. As of the latest update you now have to manually select music for your other dot or echo if you want them both to play. I keep the echo music on all day and when I shower, I stream from my dot to the shower radio. If I ask Dot alexa to play 60's music, she says you already have a device playing and would I rather hear it on this device. If you say yes, my echo turns off and the dot plays. Certainly Bezo's can hire better developers than this. 

I still cannot fathom the idea that the developers think this update is an improvement. It is the exact opposite. Volume control and "now playing " features are no longer static at the bottom of the screen. Latest version May 9, 2017 cripples the ability to quickly access volume control on iPhone. Can take as many as 4 steps just to get to a volume button. And the time between these steps is not "snappy", if you will. The finger slide volume control is buggy. You can't even see the volume number because it's directly under your finger tip. Pitiful pitiful implementation. App is clunky and slow to respond to touches on iPhone 6 plus. I would love to revert to the older version.

review:
Feb 2018 review. My external blue tooth speaker will no longer work with Alexa Dot. Period! It took some figuring out but now, instead of turning on Alexa music, then my blue tooth shower radio and instantly hearing music, I have to go into settings, blue tooth, and manually connect my external speaker each time. Add to that the fact that ‚Äúrecent‚Äù music stations rarely work now. I have to go directly to the Tunein option and start music from there. And the downhill slide continues. 

Sept 2017 review-This app continues to devolve with each update. As of the latest update you now have to manually select music for your other dot or echo if you want them both to play. I keep the echo music on all day and when I shower, I stream from my dot to the shower radio. If I ask Dot alexa to play 60's music, she says you already have a device playing and would I rather hear it on this device. If you say yes, my echo turns off and the dot plays. Certainly Bezo's can hire better developers than this. 

I still cannot fathom the idea that the developers think this update is an improvement. It is the exact opposite. Volume control and "now playing " features are no longer static at the bottom of the screen. Latest version May 9, 2017 cripples the ability to quickly access volume control on iPhone. Can take as many as 4 steps just to get to a volume button. And the time between these steps is not "snappy", if you will. The finger slide volume control is buggy. You can't even see the volume number because it's directly under your finger tip. Pitiful pitiful implementation. App is clunky and slow to respond to touches on iPhone 6 plus. I would love to revert to the older version.

review:
Continued problems with external Bluetooth speaker for Dot. What the hell are these developers doing? They are literally forcing people to google and Apple. In the good ole days before this app became too bloated for its on good, i could turn on my external Bluetooth speaker, ask my Alexa Dot to play music and it would automatically play through my external speaker. Those days are gone people!! LISTEN TO ME!!!! THEY ARE GONE!! NO MORE!!! Now I have to pair the dot and speaker each time I want to use the external speaker. It‚Äôs a multi-step time consuming process. These developers must be getting minimum wage as there is absolutely no incentive to get an app out there that works. They fix one thing and break another. I‚Äôm on the verge of going with Apple new home device, or even google for that matter. 

Feb 2018 review. My external blue tooth speaker will no longer work with Alexa Dot. Period! It took some figuring out but now, instead of turning on Alexa music, then my blue tooth shower radio and instantly hearing music, I have to go into settings, blue tooth, and manually connect my external speaker each time. Add to that the fact that ‚Äúrecent‚Äù music stations rarely work now. I have to go directly to the Tunein option and start music from there. And the downhill slide continues. 

Sept 2017 review-This app continues to devolve with each update. As of the latest update you now have to manually select music for your other dot or echo if you want them both to play. I keep the echo music on all day and when I shower, I stream from my dot to the shower radio. If I ask Dot alexa to play 60's music, she says you already have a device playing and would I rather hear it on this device. If you say yes, my echo turns off and the dot plays. Certainly Bezo's can hire better developers than this. 

I still cannot fathom the idea that the developers think this update is an improvement. It is the exact opposite. Volume control and "now playing " features are no longer static at the bottom of the screen. Latest version May 9, 2017 cripples the ability to quickly access volume control on iPhone. Can take as many as 4 steps just to get to a volume button. And the time between these steps is not "snappy", if you will. The finger slide volume control is buggy. You can't even see the volume number because it's directly under your finger tip. Pitiful pitiful implementation. App is clunky and slow to respond to touches on iPhone 6 plus. I would love to revert to the older version.

review: I love the app and the echo for itself! But it would really be great if Alexa could actually tell you where your stuff is at rather than telling you when it should arrive. Common sense! Why ask her where your stuff is if she won't tell you where?

I love and depend on Alexa, despite some of its kinks and limitations. In my house I‚Äôve got good Internet and haven‚Äôt had many connectivity issues. I‚Äôve got most of my main lights connected to Alexa and love the customized news updates that have become part of my morning routine. I‚Äôve connected it to my sound system so my music comes through in Bose surround. Wonderful.

My mom lives in the basement of a NY brownstone and has poor Internet connectivity. She had all kinds of bridging issues with the 1st generation echo and Philips Hue light bulbs and an old iPhone 5. I‚Äôve upgraded her to the latest of everything (she is still waiting for Fios to come into her area and continues to suffer from poor internet access) and although it took a while, with calls to help desks, she‚Äôs now got everything purring including her thermostat control with echo bee.

Beware the latest Alexa update. It does the thing where you have to renter your use name and password, and my Alexa was offline until I could do that. A real pain, as I just got out of surgery and am quite dependent on the voice control, etc.

I can‚Äôt really compare w Google Home and others. It‚Äôs not perfect. But I‚Äôve gotten familiar with it and developed some loyalty so I don‚Äôt foresee myself changing unless things get really bad.

review:
This app does some great things (I like the reminders, in particular), but there is a lot of room for improvement. 

One area that would make this app much more useful - improving the LISTS feature. I love the idea of using my echo to add things to my shopping list. But unlike other shopping list apps, this is missing out on 2 features:
1) CRUCIAL: when an item is checked off, it should be moved to the bottom of the list, so you can easily see what you still need to get. 
2) it would be nice if it automatically categorized items for you, or allowed you to create categories (like produce, dairy, meats, bulk). This helps me save time in a store bc I don‚Äôt have to go back to an area where I forgot something. At the very least, it would be nice if you could simply drag the items to change the order around after entering them.

title: Started out bad and is getting worse

review:
Update: 2/14/18.  Happy to report that Amazon has redesigned the volume slider so that it runs across the top of the app and is now much easier to use. I still wish they would provide an option for the app to start up with in the music mode as that is what I use the app for 95% of the time. Still not great as the interface is poorly designed and somewhat buggy, but I changed my rating from a 2 to 3 for average.

Why is it that that companies feel that they must constantly update apps that are perfectly functional in the first place. In this case, Amazon felt that they needed to completely overhaul the UI for an app that was already good (not great) and made it MUCH worse. One thing that is particularly bothersome to me is that the volume slider which use to be fine, is now very difficult to use. As soon as you touch it the volume jumps down two levels, and then is very difficult to adjust. The button is so small you can't see it or the volume level while adjusting. Did this app undergo any UAT? This update is very disappointing.
.

author: CBizzleüí™
title: iPhone X support

review:
If you don‚Äôt sign up for an Amazon Voice calling service you are not allowed to use this app. It simply won‚Äôt let you open it without signing up for a service most people don‚Äôt want. 

Since this app is literally the only way to manage your Echo devices, Amazon is holding them hostage until you meet their unreasonable demand of enabling a voice calling service in your home on an always on speaker phone in your home. 

Only Amazon can get away with this nonsense. If Apple forced users to sign up for a service which lets others invade your home privacy there would be blood in the streets. 

Considering all that Alexa is good for is turning lights on and off and playing music, I think Amazon is shooting themselves in the foot here by forcing their BS on Apple users.

author: DylanChrisGreene
title: iPhone X ‚Äúsupport‚Äù

review:
So there was an update to the Alexa app Feb 14, 2018. As usual, nothing specific listed in the update description other than the usual rubber stamped ‚Äúimprovements‚Äù crap. But many problems still persist. Automatic Bluetooth connection to external speakers (Dot) is still a thing of the past. Now requires multi-step paring each time. The app is total garbage!

Continued problems with external Bluetooth speaker for Dot. What the hell are these developers doing? They are literally forcing people to google and Apple. In the good ole days before this app became too bloated for its on good, i could turn on my external Bluetooth speaker, ask my Alexa Dot to play music and it would automatically play through my external speaker. Those days are gone people!! LISTEN TO ME!!!! THEY ARE GONE!! NO MORE!!! Now I have to pair the dot and speaker each time I want to use the external speaker. It‚Äôs a multi-step time consuming process. These developers must be getting minimum wage as there is absolutely no incentive to get an app out there that works. They fix one thing and break another. I‚Äôm on the verge of going with Apple new home device, or even google for that matter. 

Feb 2018 review. My external blue tooth speaker will no longer work with Alexa Dot. Period! It took some figuring out but now, instead of turning on Alexa music, then my blue tooth shower radio and instantly hearing music, I have to go into settings, blue tooth, and manually connect my external speaker each time. Add to that the fact that ‚Äúrecent‚Äù music stations rarely work now. I have to go directly to the Tunein option and start music from there. And the downhill slide continues. 

Sept 2017 review-This app continues to devolve with each update. As of the latest update you now have to manually select music for your other dot or echo if you want them both to play. I keep the echo music on all day and when I shower, I stream from my dot to the shower radio. If I ask Dot alexa to play 60's music, she says you already have a device playing and would I rather hear it on this device. If you say yes, my echo turns off and the dot plays. Certainly Bezo's can hire better developers than this. 

I still cannot fathom the idea that the developers think this update is an improvement. It is the exact opposite. Volume control and "now playing " features are no longer static at the bottom of the screen. Latest version May 9, 2017 cripples the ability to quickly access volume control on iPhone. Can take as many as 4 steps just to get to a volume button. And the time between these steps is not "snappy", if you will. The finger slide volume control is buggy. You can't even see the volume number because it's directly under your finger tip. Pitiful pitiful implementation. App is clunky and slow to respond to touches on iPhone 6 plus. I would love to revert to the older version.

review:
Im already HUGELY concerned about Echo‚Äôs privacy issues, as Amazon demands that ALL of your contacts be uploaded to their servers if you want to use their calling/messaging system between other Echo users. 

Considering the above, this new ‚Äúfeature‚Äù is very suspect from a privacy standpoint. ‚ÄúKnow when contacts are online‚Äù? With no further detail than this? 

Even if I dont upload my contacts, does that mean my contacts can upload theirs and know when Im online? I dont have to explain why this is a major privacy intrusion. 

Honestly, Id love to use the calling/messaging feature... BUT with ONLY the contacts I choose to share with Amazon‚ÄîAND with those contacts‚Äô approval. 

Its 2018 Amazon. Were in a day and age that you should know better by now. Please get your act together.

title: Music

review:
Noted that the Alexa app continues to scan, find, and interact with Philips Hue lights/bridge even after it has been disassociated from the bridge on both Amazon and Meethue portals. The behavior persisted even when the hue bridge and the Echo Dot were wiped/reset. All you have to do is open the Alex App and rescan for Smart Devices without installing the related skill.

The Alexa app also does not prompt iOS users for permission to access HomeKit as expected from a Privacy prospective.

To be clear, if I do not want Alexa to have access, the app should respect that anything else is a security concern.
author: ManuelJR1
title: HomeKit & Philips Hue lights security concern

review:
We got echo show to use drop in feature. Our elderly parents often have hard time answer calls and drop in works like a charm. However, they Alex app which is the only way you can drop in is not available in South Korea iOS AppStore.

It is very frustrating not being able to have it installed on my sister‚Äôs iPhone. We don‚Äôt care about any other support. Just please let us download the app in South Korean AppStre.

I know Amazon is very number driven, and our request constitutes a tiny portion of users, so I‚Äôm afraid it will go to a backlog. All I‚Äôm asking for is a single check when publishing the app in the AppStore to make it available in Korea. I really hope they get this feedback and act on it instead of quantifying that there‚Äôs only few users who wants it and chuck it to the side.. would mean so much for us!!
